Once upon a time, Rabbi Shlomo Carlebach was asked to share a story about a Chassidic Rebbe who had made a deep impression on him. Rabbi Carlebach smiled and began to speak.

"There was once a great Rebbe who lived in a small town in Poland," he said. "He was known throughout the region for his deep wisdom and his ability to heal people's souls. People would come from far and wide to seek his guidance and his blessings."

"One day, a man came to the Rebbe in great distress. He had lost his job and had no money to feed his family. He was at his wit's end and didn't know what to do."

"The Rebbe listened to the man's story and then said to him, 'My dear friend, I understand your pain. But I want you to know that you are not alone. God is always with you, even in the darkest moments of your life. And I am here to help you.'"

"The Rebbe then gave the man a small piece of bread and told him to take it home to his family. He also gave him a blessing and told him that everything would be all right."

"The man went home and shared the bread with his family. They were overjoyed and grateful for the small gift. And then, just as the Rebbe had said, a miracle happened. The man's former employer came to him the next day and offered him his job back, along with a raise in pay."

"The man was amazed and grateful. He went back to the Rebbe and thanked him for his help. The Rebbe smiled and said, 'My dear friend, it was not me who helped you. It was God who helped you. I am just a vessel for His blessings.'"

Rabbi Carlebach paused and looked around the room. "This story has stayed with me all these years," he said. "It reminds me that we are all connected to something greater than ourselves, and that even in our darkest moments, we can find hope and light. And it reminds me of the power of kindness and compassion, and how a small act of generosity can change someone's life."
